html:
Etymology 1[edit]

From pilus (“hair”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈpi.loː/, [ˈpɪ.lˠoː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈpi.lo/, [ˈpiː.lɔ]

Verb[edit]

pilō (present infinitive pilāre, perfect active pilāvī, supine pilātum); first conjugation

  1. (intransitive) I put forth hairs, grow hairy.
  2. (transitive) I deprive of hair, make bald, depilate.
  3. (transitive, figurative) I plunder, pillage.

Derived terms[edit]
  • dēpilō
  • pilātrīx
  • pilātus
Related terms[edit]
  • pilōsus
  • pilus
Descendants[edit]
  • Catalan: pelar
  • French: peler
  • Friulian: pelâ
  • Italian: pelare
  • Occitan: pelar
  • Portuguese: pelar
  • Sicilian: pilari
  • Spanish: pelar
  • Venetian: pełar

Etymology 2[edit]

Denominal from pīla (“pillar, column”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈpiː.loː/, [ˈpiː.lˠoː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈpi.lo/, [ˈpiː.lɔ]

Verb[edit]

pīlō (present infinitive pīlāre, supine pīlātum); first conjugation, no perfect stem

  1. I ram down, fix firmly.
Conjugation[edit]

Descendants[edit]
  • French: piler
  • Occitan: pilar
  • Portuguese: pilar
  • Romanian: împila
  • Spanish: pilar

Etymology 3[edit]

See the Medieval Latin pillō (“chaff”).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈpiː.loː/, [ˈpiː.lˠoː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈpi.lo/, [ˈpiː.lɔ]

Noun[edit]

pīlō f (genitive pīlōnis); third declension

  1. Alternative form of pillō
Declension[edit]

Third-declension noun.

Case Singular Plural
Nominative pīlō pīlōnēs
Genitive pīlōnis pīlōnum
Dative pīlōnī pīlōnibus
Accusative pīlōnem pīlōnēs
Ablative pīlōne pīlōnibus
Vocative pīlō pīlōnēs

  • pilo in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • pilo in Charles du Fresne du Cange’s Glossarium Mediæ et Infimæ Latinitatis (augmented edition, 1883–1887)
  • pilo in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
